newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: INL QUASHES TALK OF NEWSPAPER PRICE HIKES.
newsitem.headline: INL QUASHES TALK OF NEWSPAPER PRICE HIKES.

text.p: INL managing director Mike Robson on Wednesday quashed speculation the publisher was about to raise cover prices on its New Zealand newspapers.
INL recently raised cover prices on a number of its Saturday and weekend publications, including the Saturday edition of The Christchurch Press to 90 NZ cents from 70 cents.
"But beyond that we don't have any plans," Robson told Reuters.
Analysts expected INL, which also publishes Wellington's Evening Post and The Dominion, to raise cover prices on at least the Saturday editions of its other major papers.
They said the increased cover price of Auckland's New Zealand Herald, published by INL competitor Wilson and Horton, left the door open for INL to hike its Wellington newspaper prices.
The daily price of the Herald rose to 90 cents from 70 cents on June 3.

"It would be a fair assumption to say that INL has a little bit of a cover price rise up its sleeve," one analyst said, adding that a cover price rise would help INL to offset poor advertising volumes in the slow New Zealand economy.

"The economy has turned down for them very badly in the last quarter and advertising is poor, so if it was just that you'd have to say the company had a nasty outlook for the next half year. But they've got a cover price rise up their sleeve and they've just put in some ad rate increases," he said.

INL, 49.5 percent owned by Rupert Murdoch's News Corp, is due to report its results for the 1996/97 year on Friday and analysts expect a bottom line profit of about $50 million, up from $47.2 million last year.
This figure includes abnormal costs in the region of $4 to $5 million, and the losses sustained by CD Rom publishing house Terabyte, which could be as much as $4 million.

Analysts said while ad volumes were suffering in the depressed economic environment, lower newsprint costs would bolster second half earnings, as would a sharp turnaround the company's magazine distributor Gordon and Gotch.

"You'll find a very stunning second half turnaround in Gotch. That's part of the abnormals -- they lopped off 100 people at the start of the year, reorganised their warehousing, just got focused on what they needed to produce out of the business, and it's working," said another analyst.

He said INL was likely to sell its U.S. operations, which include newspapers in Houston and in California, after it has concluded ongoing negotiations to purchase a 51 percent stake in Sky Network Television from U.S. consortium HKP Partners.
"They're going to sell them. Once the Sky deal is through they'll flog off the U.S. stuff." He said the combined U.S. assets could probably be sold for around NZ$40 million.
Robson said INL hoped to complete its negotiations for Sky in the next couple of weeks.
"I would hope so...but I think beyond expressing the opinion that they are proceeding in a satisfactory manner, I don't really want to go beyond that," he said.
